story.text: TORONTO Jan 3 The main index of the Toronto Stock Exchange dropped more than 100 points on Wednesday morning, as investors drove down resource and energy shares on weakness in the underlying commodities. The S&P/TSX composite index fell 105.93 points, or 0.82 percent, to 12,817.73 shortly before 11 a.m., erasing the modest 15-point gain booked in Tuesday's session. Six of the benchmark's main 10 groups advanced, but the heavyweight energy and materials groups were among the decliners, pushing down the overall market. Energy fell 3 percent, while materials -- which includes resources and gold-miner shares -- fell 1.9 percent. Zinc giant Teck Cominco Ltd. (TCKb.TO) dove C$5.78, or 6.7 percent, to C$80.15. Inmet Mining IMN.TO fell C$4.94, or 8.1 percent, to C$55.84. Among energy shares, EnCana Corp. (ECA.TO) slid C$1.73, or 3.2 percent, to C$52.62. The declines came as oil fell to below $60 a barrel, thanks to warm U.S. weather which cut heating-oil demand. Base metals also paced lower, led by copper prices, which touched their lowest levels since April. ($1=$1.17 Canadian)
story.title: toronto stock index dives 100 pts , commodities sag
